snippet: Vladimir V. Putin’s widely expected victory in Russia’s presidential election set up a confrontation with an opposition movement that has rallied tens of thousands of protesters.
abstract: Vladimir V Putin is granted a new six-year term as president of Russia, a widely expected outcome that sets the stage for a confrontation with an opposition movement that has already rallied tens of thousands of protesters; amid renewed allegations of voting fraud, some opposition leaders called for demonstrations beyond those allowed by government permits, raising the prospect of a sharp response from the authorities that could threaten to undercut Putin’s promise of stability.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Glenn Kates, Anastasia Sadovskaya, Michael Schwirtz, Olga Slobodchikova and Anna Tikhomirova from Moscow, and Andrew E. Kramer from Grozny, Russia.

lead_paragraph: Vladimir V. Putin’s widely expected victory in Russia’s presidential election set up a confrontation with an opposition movement that has rallied tens of thousands of protesters.

headline.seo: Putin Wins Presidency, but Opposition Keeps Pressure
headline.main: Putin Wins, but Opposition Keeps Pressing
headline.print_headline: Putin Wins Vote, But Opposition Keeps Pressing
